blocks.text:
Differentiating again, 
\[ \frac{d^2y}{dx^2} = \frac{E}{I}(u - 2x) + \frac{1}{E} \left( \frac{d}{dx} \left( -2 \sigma \right) \right) \] 
Carrying the differentiation one stage further, 
\[ M = EI \frac{d^2y}{dx^2} \] 
Physical meanings may now be attached to these various derivatives. Referring to Fig. 10, consider a section of the beam at distance from the fixed end. To the right of this section there is a length \( L \) attached to a load with tension \( T \) on that side; the total load or net downward force on this section is \[ -T = -2 \sigma \] ; and since this load is evenly distributed, it may all be supposed to be concentrated at distance \( \frac{1}{2}L \) from the section.

Now the bending moment at the section 
\[ M = force \times distance \] 
at the distance \( \frac{1}{2}L \), we find that 
\[ M = -2 \sigma \times \frac{1}{2}(L - x) = - \sigma (L - x) \] 
Comparing this result with the value found for \( M \), we notice that the two are alike except for the presence of the constants \( E \) and \( I \) that must be a measure of the bending moment.

Actually the rule connecting \( M \) and \( S \) is 
\[ M = EI \frac{d^2y}{dx^2} \] 
We will derive this rule in a later chapter. 
The shear force can be derived from this, that the shear is given by the rate of change of bending moment, thus 
\[ S = \frac{dM}{dx} = EI \frac{d^3y}{dx^3} \] 
= \( \frac{w}{x} \) .
